review.title: Enhancing QA Systems with Complex Temporal Question Processing Capabilities
review.abstract: This paper presents a multilayered architecture that enhances the capabilities of current QA systems and allows different types of complex questions or queries to be processed. The answers to these questions need to be gathered from factual information scattered throughout different documents. Specifically, we designed a specialized layer to process the different types of temporal questions. Complex temporal questions are first decomposed into simple questions, according to the temporal relations expressed in the original question. In the same way, the answers to the resulting simple questions are recomposed, fulfilling the temporal restrictions of the original complex question. A novel aspect of this approach resides in the decomposition which uses a minimal quantity of resources, with the final aim of obtaining a portable platform that is easily extensible to other languages. In this paper we also present a methodology for evaluation of the decomposition of the questions as well as the ability of the implemented temporal layer to perform at a multilingual level. The temporal layer was first performed for English, then evaluated and compared with: a) a general purpose QA system (F-measure 65.47% for QA plus English temporal layer vs. 38.01% for the general QA system), and b) a well-known QA system. Much better results were obtained for temporal questions with the multilayered system. This system was therefore extended to Spanish and very good results were again obtained in the evaluation (F-measure 40.36% for QA plus Spanish temporal layer vs. 22.94% for the general QA system).

sections.heading: 4. Architecture of a Multilayered QA System
sections.text: In order to process specific types of questions that go beyond the scope of current QA systems, this work proposes a multi-layered architecture that increases the functionality of these QA systems and allows them to solve any type of complex questions. In this work, the temporal level has been implemented. In addition, this architecture allows to add different layers to cope with questions that require other types of complex processing and are not time-oriented, such as script questions ("How do I assemble a bicycle?") or template-based questions ("What are Nelson Mandela's most important biographical data?"). Complex questions have in common the need for additional processing of the question in order to solve them adequately. The architecture presented in this essay allows to deal with different types of complex questions by superimposing additional processing layers, one for each type, on top of an existing general QA system, QA questions, as shown in Figure 1. Thus, the output of the question decomposition unit consists of: • two partial questions (Q focus and Q constraint) which are processed by a QA system to obtain an answer for each of them • time tags containing concrete data returned by the TERSEO system (Saquete et al., 2006), these tags are part of the input of the answer recomposition unit, and they are used by this unit as time constraints to filter the individual answers, and the response to the time unit is the complete Q signal.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Temporal Expression Identification and Normalization
sections.text: This module uses the TERSEO system (Saquete et al., 2006) to identify, annotate and normalize the temporal expressions in the question. With this system, implicit and explicit temporal expressions can therefore be commented on. Expressions such as "12 / 06 / 1975" are explicit, while expressions such as "two days before" are implicit and must understand the location of another complete temporal expression (TE). In this thesis, TERSEO does not use full text as input, but only a question. The temporal tags (TE attribute with a value attribute) receive the questions as the output of this module and they are used in the standard format for specific dates or periods.

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Type Identification
sections.text: The type identification module divides the question into one of the four types in the taxonomy proposed above. This identification is necessary because each type of question in the system generates a different behavior (scenario). Type 1 and type 2 questions are classified as simple, and the answer can be obtained without splitting the original question. On the other hand, questions of type 3 and type 4 must be divided into a series of simple questions. These types of questions are always type 1, type 2 or a non-time question, which are considered simple questions.The question type is classified as type 4 according to the rules in Figure 4. There are four possibilities: (a) if there is no time expression and no time signal, the question is classified as type 1; (b) if there is no time expression, but a time signal, the question is classified as type 4; (c) if there is a time expression, but no time signal, the question is classified as type 2; (d) if there is a time expression and a time signal, the question is classified as type 3.

sections.heading: 5.2 Answer Recomposition Unit
sections.text: The main task of the Answer Recomposition Unit is to obtain the final answer to the complex question using all available inputs from the decomposition unit and the answers from the QA system. The Recomposition Unit is divided into two modules: the Individual Answer Filtering module filters the possible answers to the Q focus, avoiding the non-time compatible ones, and the Answer Comparison and Composition module, which composes the answer to the original question using the order key specified by the time signal. After the complex questions have been divided by the Decomposition Unit into the Q focus and Q restriction, and the answers to these questions have been obtained by a QA system, the Recomposition Unit determines from the list of all potential answers to the Q focus, which are compatible with all time constraints obtained during the process: time expressions, time signal, and answer to the Q restriction. sections.text: The list of possible responses to the Q-Focus and the response to the Q-Restriction given by the QA system is the input of the Individual Answer Filtering module. In the case of a Q-Focus or Q-Restriction with a temporal expression, it selects only those responses that meet the temporal limitations of the TE Identification and Normalization Unit. The date of the response should be temporally compatible with the temporal day, i.e. the date of the response must be within the date values of the tag. If not, it will be rejected. Only those responses that meet the limitations go to the Response Comparison and Comparison module.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Answer Comparison and Composition
sections.text: After the answers have been filtered using the signals and the order key, the results for the Q focus are then compared with the answer to the Q constraint to determine whether they are time compatible. Time signals indicate the order relationship between the date of the answer to the Q focus and the date of the answer to the Q constraint. Only the answers that meet the compatibility determined by the time signal can be possible answers to the original question. The answer selected in this module is considered to be an answer to the complex question. Therefore, the system is capable of solving complex time questions.

sections.heading: 6. Evaluation Experiments
sections.text: The evaluation experiments carried out in this paper were initially conducted for English, and after porting the system to Spanish, the same evaluation procedure was carried out for this new language. sections.heading: 6.3 Portability to Other Languages: The Spanish Approach
sections.text: As already mentioned, the system was originally developed for English, but also extended to Spanish. As the task of the layer that handles complex questions is language-dependent, some adjustment of the system was required: (1) TERSEO was used for Spanish, (2) all time signals stored in the system were translated into Spanish, (3) the Question Splitter module was adapted to create grammatically correct Spanish "cua ́ ndo" ("when") questions.

sections.heading: 6.3.1 Decomposition Unit Evaluation for Spanish
sections.text: The results of the evaluation are presented in Table 10.In short, in the evaluation for Spanish, 174 out of a total of 200 questions were properly processed and dissected in all aspects (TE identification, type identification, temporal signal detection and, where applicable, splitting), meaning an F measure of 89.2% for the entire decomposition process. The best results were achieved by the Signal Detection Module (F measure almost 100%), but the results for Question Splitting and Type Identification (F measure around 93-94%) and TE identification and normalization were also quite good (F measure around 86%). The main errors were very similar to the English. However, some new problems emerged in Spanish (see Annex B for details), which are essentially those of: • Grammatical errors in the transformation of the second question and normalization (F measure around 86%).

The 200 timeframes created for the English test were translated manually into Spanish and used in both experiments.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions and Further Work
sections.text: This study represents a multi-layered temporary architecture that is carried out on a multilingual level, in this case in English and Spanish. This system handles complex temporal questions by dividing them into simple questions that can be answered by different types of general QA systems. In addition, the system weighs the questions over time with time information. It proposes to create a new level that goes beyond an up-to-date QA system that has two main characteristics: the complex question that is broken down into simple questions (sub-questions) by using the time signal that relates the events (Q focus), the type of information the user needs to find them.
